list.s: Sherry learned through our Future Works class that she could rise out of the mire of the welfare system and support her family.
"You can earn the money to support yourself and your family," she says.

The families of the new wage earners may feel the accomplishment in terms of a house to live in, money to purchase food -- without food stamps -- and the beginning of a family focused on success, not hopelessness.

Because Pleasant Run is the only "family" for so many, our Emancipation Fund is one way we can help a young person take the first steps into his or her new life as an independent and productive adult.
Families are being torn apart, and too often, children are the victims.
and John H., a recovering alcoholic, rebuilding a relationships with his family so they can live together again.
Today, we serve children and families with a multitude of problems: emotional, physical, psychological and sexual abuse.
Some come from families where, through therapy, there is hope for reunification.
For others, "families" are the counselors are housemates at the group homes where they live.
In 1994 Pleasant Run served 346 children and 125 families.
In 1995 we will serve over 850 children and 340 families.
The children and families who come to Pleasant Run are given the opportunity to become happy, loving, and productive members of our society.
For Pleasant Run to continue to serve abused and neglected children and their families, we need your support.
Your gift will give children and families hope for improved tomorrows.

The Hasmonean dynasty, descendants of the Maccabee family, ruled an independent Jewish Commonwealth that stretched from the Negev to the Galilee.
After the initial years of Roman administration and political infighting, Rome installed Herod (scion of a family from Idumea, a Jewish kingdom in the desert) as King of Judea.
Jews were evacuated from the Old City’s Jewish Quarter, and thousands of Arab families fled their homes in West Jerusalem.

One rapidly runs out of hands and must resort to fingers and toes, for after years of laboriously categorizing these languages, the number of different main branches (called families and subfamilies) came to about ten.
Ingeniously, certain differences between families were explained by various phonetic shifts that (inexplicably) took place in one language group but not in another.

Although certain other languages were geographically nearby, it was impossible to establish any resemblances between them, hence Basque, for example, is not classified as being in the same family with other European languages, nor are Hungarian and Finnish, both of which belong to their own group.

The languages discussed here are what are usually called the Indo-European family; similar family trees could be drawn for the Semitic languages, Sino-Tibetan, Japanese, Bantu, Malayo-Polynesian, and so on.

The languages discussed here are what are usually called the Indo-European family; similar family trees could be drawn for the Semitic languages, Sino-Tibetan, Japanese, Bantu, Malayo-Polynesian, and so on.

In most cases, they dealt with words and functional elements, creating what are called reconstructions in hypothetical family prototypes called, variously, Proto-Latin, Proto-Greek, Proto-Germanic, Proto-Indo-Iranian, and so forth, the ultimate goal being to posit a single language called Proto-Indo-European.

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: Family Words

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: In 1962, American Speech published “Family Words in English,” by Allen Walker Read, which was reprinted in VERBATIM Vol. I, No. 4, (1975).

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: The article is a classic, probably the first on the subject to appear in a scholarly journal, though there are other informal references to family language, some of which are documented by Dickson in his Bibliography.

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: Family words and expressions crop up everywhere.

Some are quite unique and their reporters cannot imagine their origin; others, like Penn Station , “what one family terms a child's misinterpretation of a famous line or phrase,” are clear: the generic term comes from the Lord's Prayer—“And lead us not into Penn Station.”
Many people know F.H.B. for `family hold back,' an exhortation ensuring ample provender for guests.

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: There are many interesting entries in Family Words which, as far as I know, is the first documentation of the genre.
(In the VERBATIM family, some suffer from Fowler's pip , an affliction affecting language fanatics who base a slavish purism on a literal interpretation of Modern English Usage .)

s.comment: "Family words" refering to a particular kind of word

list.s: Family Words is useful and fun.
